header.beta: BETA: This is a tool in development. We welcome your feedback.
header.title: Data Suitability Assessment Tool

footer.copyright: © Statistics Canada - Data Suitability Assessment Tool.
footer.builtWith: Built with React

frontPage.intro: The Data Suitability Assessment Tool is designed to help assess if non-official data are considered fit for purpose to contribute to Canada's reporting on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs).
frontPage.assessmentInfo: By using this tool, you will be able to assess your data against Statistics Canada's:

bulletPoints.item1: core data ethics principles for data collection, editing, and dissemination.
bulletPoints.item2: dimensions of quality for producing relevant and robust statistical information.

frontPage.usage: If you wish to pursue the assessment of your data for a potential SDG reporting, please contact us with your submission once the data have been evaluated successfully with this tool.
frontPage.noteToUsers: Please note that this Data Suitability Assessment Tool is not sufficient to assess if the data meets official statistics standards.
frontPage.contactInfo: Do not hesitate to contact Statistics Canada's SDG team should you have any questions.

table.privacyDetails: This Data Suitability Assessment Tool performs all assessments locally in the user's browser. No data is collected, stored, or transmitted to Statistics Canada.

intro.part1: This first part is an assessment of the data against Statistics Canada's core principles for data collection, editing and dissemination.
intro.part2: Please evaluate each element to confirm whether the data align with the principles or not.

results.title: Results of the Assessment Against Statistics Canada's Core Data Ethics Principles:
results.passMessage: As evaluated above against Statistics Canada's data ethics principles, the data are considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting.
results.failMessage: As evaluated above against Statistics Canada's data ethics principles, the data are not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting. Please revise your data to ensure that all data ethics principles are met to be considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting.

alerts.answerAll: Please provide answers to all criteria.

intro.part1: The second part of the evaluation rests on five of the six dimensions of quality developed and used by Statistics Canada. The dimension evaluating the relevance is not included below as it is an element evaluated by the Benefit to Canadians core principle. A definition and a series of criteria are provided with each dimension. Each dimension is evaluated and scored based on the compliance to the criteria, and an aggregated pass/fail rating is returned.
intro.part2: Please evaluate each criterion to confirm whether the data align with the principles or not by selecting the checkbox next to the criterion. An unselected criterion will be considered as not met.

tooltip.title: Points correspond to the number of criteria satisfied:
tooltip.exceptions: Please note that the 'Accessibility and clarity' dimension contains only 2 criteria; satisfying both criteria (2/2) results in the maximum score of 3 points (High).

summary.title: Results of the Assessment Against Statistics Canada's Dimensions of Quality:
summary.tableCaption: Detailed Dimensions of Data Quality Scores

interpretation.low: The quality of the data as evaluated above is not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting, please consider addressing some of the evaluation criteria to improve its quality if possible.
interpretation.medium: The quality of the data as evaluated above is considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting but could be improved, please consider addressing some of the evaluation criteria if possible.
interpretation.high: The quality of the data as evaluated above is considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting.
interpretation.fail: The quality of the data as evaluated above has at least one dimension of data quality that is not sufficient and is therefore not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting. Please consider addressing some of the evaluation criteria to improve its quality if possible.

messages.bothPass: The data passed both assessments and are considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting.
messages.ethicsFailQualityPass: The data do not meet the core data ethics principles and are not considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting. The data must meet all core data ethics principles to be suitable for SDG reporting. Please review your data and address any missing core data ethics principles to ensure that the data are considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting.
messages.ethicsPassQualityFail: The data meet all core data ethics principles; however, they do not meet the number of dimensions of quality criteria required. As a result, the data are not deemed suitable for SDG reporting at this time. Please review your data and address any missing dimensions of quality criteria to ensure that the data are considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting.
messages.bothFail: The data do not meet the core data ethics principles and the dimensions of quality criteria, and therefore, are not fit for purpose for SDG reporting. Please review your data to ensure that all core data ethics principles and dimensions of quality criteria are met to be considered fit for purpose for SDG reporting.

export.title: Export Assessment
export.pdfPreview: A PDF report will be generated when you click Download.
export.wordPreview: A Word document report will be generated when you click Download.

principle1.explanation: The information acquired and utilized must provide a clear and easily communicated benefit to Canadians. The data must support Canada's reporting on the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) by enabling the measurement of an unreported indicator or by providing data allowing for more granular reporting of a reported indicator.
principle1.criteria: Does the information provide a clear benefit to Canadians?

principle2.explanation: If the disseminated data include potentially sensitive topics, it is important to have a plan in place to alleviate any potential harm, unfairness or risk of amplifying stereotypes and stigma on groups featured in the data. Additionally, the appropriate partners should be consulted throughout the process to discuss any potential fairness and harm issues. The data must use the appropriate terminology and categories to describe the various population groups featured.
principle2.criteria: Are potentially sensitive topics handled in a way that ensures fairness and causes no harm?

principle3.explanation: The methods used to transform the information to produce statistics must be communicated clearly to ensure transparency. The methodology used must be documented and continually monitored alongside its outputs to ensure continued robustness and relevance for the reporting.
principle3.criteria: Are the methods used monitored and communicated regularly alongside its outputs?

principle4.explanation: Protecting the privacy of respondents throughout the process is critical. Some examples of methods that can help include limiting access to confidential information to a need to know basis while limiting collection to strictly necessary information from fully consenting individuals. The privacy of respondents must be maintained during all the steps of the statistical process.
principle4.criteria: Is the privacy of respondents respected?

principle5.explanation: Ensuring that the data does not contain confidential information, such as personal information or identifying characteristics is critical to ensuring confidentiality. The data used to measure and report on Canada's progress must not include any confidential information. Furthermore, it must be impossible to connect individuals to the disseminated data.

dimension1.definition: The accuracy of statistical information is the degree to which the information correctly describes the phenomena it was designed to measure. Reliability reflects the degree to which statistical information correctly describes the phenomena it was designed to measure consistently over time. The data must accurately and reliably measure Canada's progress for a selected SDG indicator over time.
criteria: There are no or few missing values for the most important statistics
There are established verification rules for the data
Documented quality assurance processes were followed

dimension2.definition: The timeliness of statistical information refers to the delay between the information reference period and the date on which the information becomes available and punctuality refers to the difference between planned and actual availability. The data must provide a measure of Canada's progress on the SDGs at planned and regular intervals through time covering the period of the Agenda 2030.
criteria: The data is available in a timely manner
The data is released at regular intervals
The data is published on planned dates

dimension3.definition: The accessibility and clarity of data and supporting information refer to the ease with which users can learn that the information exists, find it, view it and use it. The data and its supporting information must be easily accessible and harvested to facilitate its use in Canada's reporting on the SDGs.
criteria: The data and supporting information are easily accessible
The data and supporting information are provided in an easy-to-use format

dimension4.definition: The interpretability of statistical information refers to the availability of supplementary information and metadata needed to interpret the data and possibly reproduce it. This information normally covers the underlying concepts, the reference period of the data, the variables and classifications used, the methodology of the data collection and processing. The data and any relevant information (including the ref period) must be available to support Canada's reporting on the SDGs over the Agenda 2030 (2015-2030).
criteria: A description of the methods used to collect, process and analyze the data is available to users
The definition of all variables, code sets and classifications used is provided to the users
The reference period of the data is well defined and communicated

dimension5.definition: The coherence and comparability of statistical information refer to the degree to which it can be reliably combined and compared with other statistical information and over time. The use of common concepts (e.g., terminology, classification, methodology etc.) and standards are critical to ensuring coherence and facilitate its use in Canada's reporting on the SDGs.
criteria: Comparability is maintained over time and across regions
Any inconsistencies or break in the time series are explained
